Each carton style has been designed, tested and approved to meet US DOT requirements to protect lighters from damage and prevent activation or release of gas during shipping and handling. The incoming pallets are placed into rack storage. As customer orders are received, individual pallets of lighters are transferred to the sorting area of the facility via forklift. From this location, individual cartons of lighters are placed by hand onto a conveyor system which labels each carton and collates the products required to fill each order. At the end of the conveyor, the individual cartons of products are recombined together by hand on to pallets and loaded onto trucks/trailers via forklift for shipment to the customer. 

The facility is regulated under the Program 1 requirements under the applicability criteria of 40 CFR §68.10, which means that there are no off-site consequences from the handling and storage of isobutane.  

The lighter itself is the gas container. The lighter device is made of engineering-grade plastics and metal, designed to withstand high pressures and physical damage. The gas is in the form of a liquified isobutane gas, or LPG. There are several sizes of lighters and the largest contains less than 5 grams of gas.  In this facility, the vast majority of lighters remain inside of multiple layers of packaging - the individual lighters are not handled so there is no release of the gas.  The only reasonable scenario for a gas release is the physical crushing of a lighter during handling.  Because the lighters remain in protective packaging, breakage is exceptionally rare. If a lighter is crushed, the LPG isobutane rapidly escapes from the lighter, expands quickly and typically dissipates to non-flammable levels a few feet from the release point.  Because of the small amount of gas in each container, nearly 95 lighters would have to be crushed simultaneously to produce one pound of gas - the minimum amount of gas nece

ssary to evaluate for an off-site consequence per the RMP regulation.  Breaking 95 lighters simultaneously is not a realistic scenario for this site.  In any case, there is absolutely no reasonable scenario that could result in an explosive impact that extends off site.

3.	Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies at This Facility

BIC Group maintains an overall Environmental, Health, and Safety policy which commits BIC to pollution prevention; risk prevention; regulatory compliance; continuous improvement; and awareness and involvement. The facility develops and implements programs in support of these Group commitments, including programs for accidental release prevention and emergency response.  Environmental and Safety programs are managed by a full time Manager, Environment and Safety who directly serves the BIC Charlotte, NC facilities. The Manager, Environment and Safety works with facility staff to administer several programs which contribute to release prevention including safe work practices, employee training, preventative maintenance and administrative controls designed to ensure that hazards are identified and that safety issues are identified and addressed.

4.	General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

Prevention of accidental releases at the facility is accomplished through compliance with EPA's Accidental Release Prevention provisions; compliance with federal and state environmental, safety, packaging and shipping regulations; and, the application of longstanding corporate philosophies and initiatives which help support safe operations. The following are a few of the examples of the prevention measures which are relevant to this facility:

a.	BIC Group performs extensive in-line quality testing of every individual lighter produced which not only guarantees safe and reliable operation of the product by the consumer, but also provides an additional measure of safety for all storage and war

ehousing operations.  This facility handles, stores and transports only BiC Lighters.
b.	BIC Group specifically designs and tests its packaging for lighters to minimize damage to both the packaging and the lighter during handling, storage and transportation and to prevent the accidental release and accumulation of gas.
c.	The facility trains, tests and certifies all fork truck operators, even those with previous certifications and experience.
d.	The facility employs various policies and procedures to limit the height of lighter storage and to eliminate spill hazards from the racks.
e.	The facility conducts many regular inspections including the following: weekly inspections of hazardous waste storage areas, monthly fire extinguisher inspections, weekly sprinkler control valve and PIV inspection, quarterly sprinkler flow alarm test, other semi-annual and annual sprinkler system testing.
f.	The facility is audited for risk reduction opportunities annually by its insurance carrier.
g.	The facility conducts regular safety training. 
h.	The facility requires reporting, documenting and investigating all incidents, including near misses in order to fully understand incident causes and to prevent re-occurrence or the occurrence of similar incidents.
i.	Facility supervisors conduct weekly behavioral safety observations and complete a monthly safety checklist of each facility.

5.	Five-Year Accident History

Since BIC began operations at this facility in February 1996, there have been zero accidental releases of isobutane with off-site consequences.

6.	Emergency Response Program

BIC has implemented a written Emergency Action and Contingency Plan, which has been prepared in accordance with the requirements of 29 CFR 1910.38, and other regulations including 40 CFR Part 265 Subpart D. This plan establishes detailed facility evacuation, response, and reporting procedures for potential emergencies including fires, explosions, accidental releases, power failures, natural disaster

s, bomb threats, civil disturbances, and medical emergencies. The plan designates primary and secondary Facility Emergency Coordinators who are responsible for implementing the plan during an emergency. The plan also provides for emergency training of all facility personnel. The procedures in this plan have been submitted to local emergency response agencies, including the Charlotte Mecklenburg County Emergency Management Division, Charlotte Fire Department, Charlotte Mecklenburg Police Department, Mecklenburg Emergency Medical Services Agency, select local hospitals and privately contracted emergency response contractors.  The submittal included a copy of the written plan as well as a description of the expected services each entity would render in an emergency. BIC further has invited the agencies to review and comment on the plan, to send appropriate representatives to visit the facility and to conduct emergency drills.

Emergency response steps that may be implemented in the event of an accident involving lighters include the use of portable fire extinguishers and/or response by the local fire department.  Fire protection measures at the facility are supported by an Early Suppression Fast Response (ESFR) automatic sprinkler system. 

7.	General Safety Program

The facility reports and investigates all incidents, including "near misses" where there was no property damage or injury. All employees are notified about all incidents either via email or by postings on multiple site bulletin boards and TV monitors for personnel without email.   The facility also issues a separate Accident Alert and Safety Talk program to further constructively actively engage employees in accident prevention via a 5 to 10-minute interactive session in small groups on the work floor where a lead or supervisor discusses the incident and the team brainstorms various Human Element, Organizational or Technical measures which could prevent or mitigate a similar situation.

ultiple daily aisle walks to observe, report, and remediate any unsafe conditions in the storage racks. The site conducts multiple observations of forklift operators every six months for compliance with safe operation principles.

The site safety teams meet weekly to review incidents, review safety suggestions, review the results of any aisle walks, and to create action plans. A safety training topic is presented in a 10 to 45-minute classroom session monthly.  Daily topics of 1-3 minutes are prepared by the safety personnel and presented by team leaders at the beginning of each work shift.

The facility maintains an employee-run, lean behavior-based safety program to observe and report about employee behaviors relevant to the facility's top behavioral risks.
